Premise: Referendums at times can lead to ill-informed decisions. Since the general public is politically inexperienced, they may not be able to gauge the long-term implications of their decisions.

Conclusion: Referendums are good for the society
Premise: Referendums provide an unreliable view, as the general public may have less knowledge about certain issues so they can be swayed in any direction by the politicians through aggressive speeches, false data, etc. And the lack of knowledge will leave no other choice for the people than to believe those facts.

Conclusion: India should transition to electric vehicles
Premise: As of 2019, India is importing crude oil for 82% of its oil requirement. By using electric vehicles, we can reduce the dependence on other countries for oil imports.

Conclusion: We should abolish the National Register of Citizens (NRC)
Premise: NRC increases the feeling of alienation among Muslims and animosity among orthodox Hindus, leading to communal unrest which is already on the rise since the BJP came to power.

Conclusion: We should link Aadhaar card with the Voter ID
Premise: This can be used to eliminate fake voter cards. Moreover, some people have voter cards in 2 or more areas. These duplicate voter cards can be eliminated by linking Aadhaar cards with Voter IDs.

Conclusion: Adultery should be criminalized
Premise: Law should not interfere in the personal lives.

Conclusion: Women can be in combat roles
Premise: There are no much facilities and infrastructure in Indian Army to allow women in combat roles.

Conclusion: We should promote the use of nuclear energy
Premise: Renewable energies should be our focus of action, especially how to improve the storage and transport of this energy precisely in order to be able to supply the countries that have the worst conditions to implement them.

Conclusion: We should tax heavily or refuse to import products not manufactured in the European Union that do not comply with our climate standards
Premise: Heavy taxation of imported goods will encourage the relaunch of European production, which is more environmentally friendly.

Conclusion: Wind and solar energy resources are a commodity, provided by big companies.
Premise: Energy is a human right and free energy production is a human right as well.

Conclusion: We should protect 20% of land in each European country to restore biodiversity
Premise: This is really crucial in order to stop warming, locally, eventually regionally or nationally, and globally. The more intact ecosystems we have, the more likely we can stop global warming.

Conclusion: We should promote the use of nuclear energy
Premise: Nuclear energy is not safe and it is not green because of radioactive waste. We have some conditions for sustainable green energy (at least solar, wind, biomethane etc.).

Conclusion: We should use the waste from the agri-food industry in the ruminant feed chain
Premise: allow it to be handed out to charities for consumption by those in need.

Conclusion: We should implement minimum EU social standards
Premise: To reduce poverty and inequalities, the EU should develop a legal framework guaranteeing minimum social standards, including decent living and working conditions as well as adequate social protection.

Conclusion: We should put a cap on personal wealth and annual income
Premise: Having an upper limit for annual income would make our society fairer, more inclusive, and overall a better society for everybody

Conclusion: We should return to the free market capitalist ideals in Europe and stop the advance of socialism and leftist ideology
Premise: Capitalism and the free market indeed created western wealth. However, the interesting question then is: who benefited from this wealth? Without some sort of regulation and control from the State, companies will continue what they do best, increase profit without any concern for environmental and social matters.

Conclusion: We should stop destabilizing developing countries by subsidized agricultural exports
Premise: It will take years before the local farmers will be able to give well paid jobs to the local workers. In the meantime you'll have a famine and a genocide. And I didn't even mention the effects of a sudden huge inflation wave.

Conclusion: We should reduce environment pollution by limiting number of people in Europe
Premise: Instead we need to change our behavior, reduce our consumerism and decrease our overall resource use per person.

Conclusion: We should impose an IQ test to immigrants
Premise: This is against human rights. I think advocating restricting immigration from non EU countries based on education, work skill and language literacy is a legitimate suggestion, but morally IQ tests are not acceptable and as very akin to what would be expected of a ethno-nationalist  authoritarian regime, not a union of democratic institutions.

Conclusion: We should implement a legislation on aquatic animal welfare
Premise: Fish are sentient and failure to afford them the same legal protections that we provide other animals is a gross moral and legal oversight.

Conclusion: We should remove illegal immigrants.
Premise: EU must take action. Help those in need, but only those who respect legal boundaries. Mutual respect is a cornerstone in this subject where we must set limits to protect Europe.

Conclusion: We should protect the European border.
Premise: Frontex is the way to protect the European border. It should completely take over every border, land, sea, and air. Otherwise, it will just take over all the good personnel of a member state, causing even more problems at the border.

Conclusion: We should promote collaborative civic technologies for enhancing citizen participation as an added value to collaborative urban processes
Premise: The use and promotion of civic technology contribute to a more inclusive, resident-focused urban co-governance model and build ecosystems rich in creativity and innovation, thanks to the diversity of users and perspectives that are at stake.

Conclusion: We should make cycling and micromobility the primary modes of transport in all EU cities
Premise: Having cycling and micromobility as primary modes also makes cities quieter, less congested, less polluted, safer, and simply more pleasant and liveable, particularly for children.

Conclusion: We should strengthen the public role of faith-based communities in environmental protection
Premise: Through their emphasis on wisdom, social cohesion, and interrelatedness Faith-Based Organizations can show the potential to not only effectively mobilize people on the ground in responding to climate change but more importantly to motivate large sections of society to move from their deep seeded set of core values.

Conclusion: We should recognize Esperanto as one of the cultural languages of EU citizens
Premise: Esperanto is a common language of citizens from all countries of the EU. Esperanto encounters bring them together for contact and understanding. The authorities of the European Union are called upon to support this direct communication of the citizens. It is our free choice in which language we want to talk to each other - please recognize and promote it!

Conclusion: We should legalize non-violent drug use
Premise: European institutions should take factual studies of the relative harm of different drugs into account. A UK study has shown that drugs such as cannabis and many hallucinogenic drugs are far less harmful than alcohol. The study in question was conducted by David J Nutt, Leslie A King, Lawrence D Phillips, on behalf of the Independent Scientific Committee on Drugs

Conclusion: We should stop immigration.
Premise: The organization of mass migration is a heinous crime. No more immigration from non-European or non-first-world countries.

Conclusion: We should rethink the legal state of Family Reunification.
Premise: Family Reunification creates unbearable levels of migration and acute problems of integration for several EU Member States.

Conclusion: We should remove unauthorized asylum seekers or migrants.
Premise: Many countries have the view that unauthorized asylum seekers should be removed.

Conclusion: We should promote European values and secure a Global Transition to CO2 Neutrality
Premise: I oppose tying investment to ideological convictions. Generally, there has been way too much ideology in European matters, and conflicts that derive from a conflict of worldviews within Europe have already contributed greatly to the current crisis of the EU this conference hopes to address. Specifically, when it comes to trade, all that should matter are our financial, economic, and strategic interests. Let us leave ideology to that very expensive talking shop: the European Parliament.

Conclusion: We should strengthen our ties with Ukraine and prepare for its membership in the EU
Premise: We must support countries that want to improve the welfare and rights of their citizens. If a country wants to join the EU and meets the conditions for joining, the decision to join is solely between the candidate country and the EU.

Conclusion: We should ban the trading of virtual currencies.
Premise: Cracking down on virtual currencies is not only to ensure the smooth advancement of carbon peak and carbon neutrality, but also to protect the country's financial order.

Conclusion: We should ban the trading of virtual currencies.
Premise: Cryptocurrency can change the way of value transmission, that is, it can allow the uncontrolled flow of funds around the world.

Conclusion: We should protect our privacy in the Internet age.
Premise: Most people have to rely on centralized information distribution and dissemination platforms to publish information. It is easy to control the output and control of ideology, social ideas and hotspots.

Conclusion: We should protect our privacy in the Internet age.
Premise: You can barely recover privacy. It's hard to imagine what companies do with personal information, including who they actually sell it to.

Conclusion: We should protect our privacy in the Internet age.
Premise: Recording precise data of individuals can improve individual lives; recording huge data of groups can optimize resource allocation.

Conclusion: We should restrict minors from playing online games.
Premise: Children's addiction to games may not be a problem of games in essence, but a comprehensive problem of family education, children's habits, hobby training and so on.

Conclusion: We should restrict minors from playing online games.
Premise: Instead of banning games, it might be better to increase young people's awareness of life and society, and to promote self-awareness and active thinking among students.

Conclusion: We should restrict minors from playing online games.
Premise: Rather than restricting minors to play games, parents should set a good example and spend more time with their children.

Conclusion: We should open up three-child policy to encourage childbirth.
Premise: Other measures such as subsidizing childbirth, reducing the cost of health care and education for the population, and protecting women more from the law and the workplace are more imminent.

Conclusion: We should open up three-child policy to encourage childbirth.
Premise: No matter what the social policy is, the more the society develops, the more free people are, and the more independent women are. The decline in fertility is an inevitable trend.

Conclusion: We should prohibit capital monopoly.
Premise: Capital monopolies distort market prices and undermine fair competition in the market.

Conclusion: We should vigorously develop the countryside.
Premise: Unemployment and urbanization when combined are slums and instability, so the rural areas need to be allowed to absorb the unemployed.

Conclusion: Carbon emissions trading should be limited.
Premise: Climate change is a global issue facing mankind, and with carbon dioxide emissions from all countries, greenhouse gases are surging, posing a threat to life systems.

Conclusion: Carbon emissions trading should be limited.
Premise: No one can stop global warming, which is inherently part of the Earth's geological cycle. That's why topics such as reducing CO2 emissions are a false proposition.
